chunks.content: As at most other universities, Notre Dame's students run a number of news media outlets. The nine student-run outlets include three newspapers, both a radio and television station, and several magazines and journals.

metadata.topic: Overview of student-run media at Notre Dame

chunks.content: Begun as a one-page journal in September 1876, the Scholastic magazine is issued twice monthly and claims to be the oldest continuous collegiate publication in the United States.

metadata.topic: Scholastic magazine history and publication frequency

chunks.content: The other magazine, The Juggler, is released twice a year and focuses on student literature and artwork. The Dome yearbook is published annually.

metadata.topic: Other student publications: The Juggler and The Dome

chunks.content: The newspapers have varying publication interests, with The Observer published daily and mainly reporting university and other news, and staffed by students from both Notre Dame and Saint Mary's College.

metadata.topic: The Observer newspaper and its focus

chunks.content: Unlike Scholastic and The Dome, The Observer is an independent publication and does not have a faculty advisor or any editorial oversight from the University.

In 1987, when some students believed that The Observer began to show a conservative bias, a liberal newspaper, Common Sense was published. Likewise, in 2003, when other students believed that the paper showed a liberal bias, the conservative paper Irish Rover went into production.

metadata.topic: Response publications to perceived biases in The Observer

chunks.content: Neither paper is published as often as The Observer; however, all three are distributed to all students. Finally, in Spring 2008 an undergraduate journal for political science research, Beyond Politics, made its debut.

metadata.topic: Distribution of publications and introduction of Beyond Politics
